newsitem.title: FRANCE: Credit Lyonnais shares jump on recovery, sale hopes.
newsitem.headline: Credit Lyonnais shares jump on recovery, sale hopes.

text.p: Shares of state-controlled Credit Lyonnais jumped more than five percent on Friday, boosted by robust first-quarter results and investor hopes that its privatisation could be accelerated.
The shares, which make up around 20 percent of the bank's capital but carry no voting rights, closed up 5.24 percent at 233.10 francs.
Prime Minister Alain Juppe said on Thursday the government might "perhaps" privatise the bank this year instead of late 1998 or early 1999 as planned.

On the same day, Credit Lyonnais issued a statement saying its first quarter profit, excluding exceptionals and tax, was significantly higher than the corresponding year-earlier period but gave no precise figures.
The bank has staged an unexpectedly strong recovery, helped by massive amounts of state aid, after nearly collapsing in the early 1990s under the weight of an ill-fated lending spree.

The newspaper Le Figaro said on Friday that U.S. investment groups and British lending institutions were interested in the privatisation and might be willing to contribute to a recapitalisation, avoiding the need for another state bailout.
Some media reports say the bank could need a further eight to 12 billion franc ($1.4-2.1 billion) injection to boost is solvency ratios.
One analyst suggested the government might seek first to assemble a group of "pure financial" investors who would take a 20 to 30 percent stake, and then banking and insurance partners.
"They will want to get some pure financial partners around the table, and then look for insurers and banks to take stakes," he said. "The public would hold the rest."
Analysts noted, however, the bank had a heavy asset disposal agenda to win European Commission approval for state help.
They said it was more likely the bank would be ready for sale in early 1998. "Many investors would prefer a full year of solid operating performance than half a year," said one.
"But I guess it's an encouraging sign of the underlying trend at Credit Lyonnais that the government is talking about privatising it now," another said.
The bank's shares, formally called investment certificates, have rocketed more than 70 percent since the start of the year on the bank's financial recovery and expected sale.
One Paris analyst, who has a buy recommendation on the certificates, said they could reach 285 francs long term.

Analysts expect the bank to have profits of around 1.3 billion francs ($230 million) this year and 2.4 billion in 1998. It posted a profit of 202 million francs in 1996 after limping back into the black in 1995 with a profit of 13 million francs.
It lost 21 billion francs between 1992 and 1994. ($ = 5.696 French Francs)
